title: I was sued in a Civil Court by a credit card company? But should I attend this conference at all to discuss about this debt?
question: I had filed Chapter 7 ( by self but screw up by the Trustee & Postal Service who changed my home address without letting me know & the appointment schedule from Court never arrived to my mail box) in result of debts to protect my under-value home (150K less and 75K over in the Mortgage Loan) and a 150K mileage car. I technically have nothing left. All 401K cashed out past couple years. One of the Bankruptcy attorney had once advised me to not to worry and no need to file any Chapter as I have nothing for the creditors to go after. I am not sure what to do next. Should I just show up and tell them point blank as I was protected under the Law for my house & furnitures & old car? OR just not show up at all? I dont have any much money to pay any attorney fee.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,State court
answers:
You should file a Notice of Stay with the state court AND attend to advise the court of the bankruptcy. You can obtain this form from occourts.org.

Hope that helps.

Yes always show up in court because if you don't a default will be entered against you and a judgment will go on your credit report where it will remain virtually forever. It sounds to me that you have either received some extremely bad legal advice or else there have been issues in understanding and following legal advice. Bankruptcy notices are sent out both electronically and also in the mail and so there is an issue there that is difficult, at the very least, to understand.

Also, 401K funds should never be tapped into to pay unsecured credit. Ever.

However, the answer to your question is YES go to court.

You may be able to obtain legal representation through a legal services office or a bar association low fee-no fee referral service.

I truly wish you the best.

If I am understanding your facts correctly, you filed for bankruptcy but for whatever reason, the bankruptcy case got dismissed or is no longer pending, so you currently do not have the temporary protection of the automatic stay.

if this is correct, then you should still try your best to defend the civil court lawsuits, even it is to just show up in court.
